awd_titl_txt: NetSE: Large: Collaborative Research:Contagion in Large Socio-Communication Networks
awd_abstract_narration: Simple contagion processes underlie various phenomena on complex networks, such as the spread of diseases on social-contact networks and information in communication networks; understanding their dynamics and developing control mechanisms are key issues in numerous applications. The goals of this proposal are: (i) Developing methods to construct synthetic relational networks using partial and noisy data; (ii) Understanding the structure of these networks and the contagion processes, and especially important network properties and typical patterns that have an impact on the dynamics of contagion; (iii) Developing techniques to control the spread of contagion processes, and to detect, prevent and arrest cascading failures in coupled socio-technical networks; and (iv) Understanding the co-evolution between the networks and dynamics, and using this to refine their models, and the strategies to control them.

org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The project dealt with the problem of spread of opinions, attitudes, beliefs, worms in social and communication networks. The project useed the notion of contagion broadly to mean transmitted phenomena such as diseases, opinions, fads, trends, norms, and any phenomena that is understood in terms of the dynamics of the transmission process when a group of agents interact. Particularly important for the project were the rapidly-growing social and communication networks such as Twitter and Facebook, which have emerged as networks over which diverse contagion spreads. Despite the ubiquity of networks and the widespread appreciation of the importance of contagion processes over them, a conceptually systematic and rigorous computational approach for understanding them was lacking.

The project investigated and developed a framework for addressing cascade prediction problems. First the theoretical model of future growth of a cascade was developed. Then, on a large sample of photo reshare cascades on Facebook, the project found strong performance in predicting whether a cascade will continue to grow in the future. The project discovered that the relative growth of a cascade becomes more predictable as we observed more of its reshares, that temporal and structural features are key predictors of cascade size, and that initially, breadth, rather than depth in a cascade is a better indicator of larger cascades. Furthermore, the prediction performance is robust in the sense that multiple distinct classes of features all achieve similar performance. And last, it was also discovered that temporal features are predictive of a cascade's eventual shape. Observing independent cascades of the same content, the project found that while these cascades differ greatly in size, we are still able to predict which ends up the largest.
